I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In  2003,  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  provided  technical  assistance  to  the 
Government of Nepal to establish an economic policy network1 to facilitate policy dialogue 
among  various  stakeholders,  foster  consensus,  and  secure  commitment  to  facilitate 
implementation of the policy reform agenda. The Government has asked ADB to continue this 
support through a second phase. Consequently, this TA, Economic Policy Network II, was 
included in the 2007 program. The Fact-Finding Mission during 14–23 August 2007 gathered 
inputs  on  the  TA  scope  and  design;  and  met  with  government  agencies,  private  sector 
organizations,  and  policy  research  institutions.  It  reached  an  understanding  with  the 
Government  on  the  TA  objectives,  scope,  costs  and  financing,  tentative  implementation 
arrangements, and counterpart support.2 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Nepal implemented a policy reform agenda in the early 1990s to accelerate the pace of 
economic development and reduce poverty in the country. However, the progress on the policy 
reforms has been inadequate due to weaknesses in policy formulation and implementation. The 
2003 ADB-supported TA helped the Government to (i) develop a network for economic policy 
dialogue  and  analysis;  (ii)  undertake  policy  research  and  analysis,  and  information 
dissemination  on  several  policy  issues,  and  (iii)  strengthen  networking  among  government 
agencies, private sector, academic institutions, and nongovernment organizations. 
 
3.  However, despite strong leadership by the Government line ministries, adoption and 
implementation of the policy recommendations has been slow. The reform process needs to be 
sustained  and  consolidated  as  policy  reforms  involve  the  competing  interests  of  different 
stakeholders. Further, since implementation of the sector policy recommendations is largely 
determined by the line ministries, their ownership needs to be deepened to ensure that they 
undertake the policy reforms. The implementation status of the first phase of the support must 
be assessed, and conditions identified to enhance implementation of policy recommendations.  
 
4.  The  Government  is  preparing  a  3-year  interim  development  plan  to  address  the 
development challenges during the ongoing political transition. The main strategies identified in 
the plan are reconstruction and rehabilitation of physical infrastructure, economic recovery, 
inclusive development, and economic and social transformation. The plan also aims to introduce 
policy  reforms  to  move  the  development  agenda  forward.  Owing  to  the  country’s  political 
developments, some emerging areas of policy need sound analysis. Based on the analysis of 
the  current  situation  and  consultations  with  relevant  stakeholders,  the  following  thematic 
clusters have been identified for related policy analysis:  
 
(i)  Macroeconomic management and inclusive growth. Continued low growth is 
a serious concern and needs immediate attention to formulate suitable policies 
for achieving a higher growth rate. Appropriate policy initiatives are required to 
meet the challenge of rising inequality. Similarly, management and utilization of 
foreign aid and regulation of nonbanking financial institutions need attention to 
ensure sustainable economic growth and poverty reduction.  
 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2003. Technical Assistance to Nepal for Establishing Economic Policy Network. Manila (TA 4288-NEP, 
approved in December 2003 and closed on 31 December 2006). 
2  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 24 July 2007.

2     
(ii)  Decentralized governance. A transparent and efficient governance system is 
vital for effective implementation of policies and programs, and effective delivery 
of  local  services.  In  view  of  the  political  decision  to  adopt  federalism,  huge 
challenges in terms of the relationship of the central and local governments must 
be resolved for resource sharing, fiscal federalism, and other related issues. 
 
(iii)  Trade,  regional  integration,  and  private  sector  development.  Industrial 
performance  has  been  weak  in  recent  years,  often  due  to  problems  of 
adjustments to the emerging new world trade order with regard to the World 
Trade  Organization,  and  other  regional  and  bilateral  trade  agreements.  The 
Government  must  have  strategies  to  gain  from  these  international  trading 
arrangements and possess a strong position with clarity on the benefits to the 
country. Options need to be explored to devise policies to benefit from these 
international trading arrangements. Private sector investment must be attracted 
to  expand  industrial  activities  and  become  globally  competitive.  Creating  an 
enabling  environment  with  suitable  policies  for  attracting  private  sector 
investment remains crucial. 
 
(iv)  Social  inclusion  and  human  development.  Despite  marked  progress  in 
poverty  reduction,  human  development  indicators  are  not  very  encouraging, 
especially  in  some  sections  of  society.  The  geographic  aspects  of  human 
development and horizontal inequality require the attention of policy makers. 
Social policies to enhance access of all communities from all parts of country to 
economic  opportunities  would  yield  sustained  economic  development.  At  the 
same time, opportunities should be created for the general public to avail of 
public services.  
 
(v)  Infrastructure development. Poor infrastructure is a major barrier to growth. 
The  role  of  infrastructure  for  poverty  reduction  by  creating  connectivity, 
particularly in rural areas, has emerged as an important policy objective. Policies 
for improving transport, communications, energy, and other related infrastructure 
should be devised. 
 
(vi)  Agriculture  and  rural  development.  A  concerted  effort  will  be  required  to 
increase the productivity of the agriculture sector to enhance rural income and 
employment  growth,  and  concurrently  address  commercialization.  A  huge 
investment is required to transform the traditional subsistence agriculture into a 
vibrant commercial activity.  
 
5.  Various findings and recommendations of the 2003 TA are incorporated in the fiscal 
budgets of FY2006 and FY2007 and the 3-year interim development plan. However, the TA was 
found to lack continuity due to the lack of a devoted institution for research and analyses on the 
public policy reform agenda and process. The experiences gained through TA implementation 
confirm a strong demand for an institution with a defined constituency to undertake networking 
with all concerned stakeholders on the public policy reform agenda. The lessons from the TA3 
suggest a need to institutionalize the government system network created for public policy 
analysis. The institution could serve as a focal body to identify policy issues; and undertake 
policy dialogue with various stakeholders including government agencies, private sector, other

(TA 4288).

3                         
   
policy  institutions,  individual  experts,  and  nongovernment  organizations;  and  foster  mutual 
benefits and consensus among them. It would also coordinate activities related to the pubic 
policy reform agenda and be responsible for monitoring and evaluation. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The TA aims to establish a formal process of informed policy making in the Government 
wherein the policies developed and recommended are adopted to promote growth and reduce 
poverty. The TA will help to establish an institution with responsibility to undertake networking of 
the socioeconomic reform agenda and policy analysis of the Government for achieving poverty 
reduction and human development. It will contribute to institutional capacity development for 
informed policy-making processes of the Government. The ownership and consensus on the 
policy reforms required for achieving the larger objective of sustainable growth and development 
in Nepal will be strengthened.  
 
7.  The TA outputs include (i) plan of action for implementing the policy recommendations 
based on review and assessment of the 2003 TA, (ii) policy papers based on research and 
analysis  on  identified  and  emerging  issues  under  the  specified  thematic  clusters,  (iii) 
establishment of an institution in the Government as a focal body to undertake networking and 
foster policy dialogue among various stakeholders, and (iv) a mechanism for monitoring and 
evaluation of the policy reform agenda and impacts. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  A thorough assessment of internalization and use of the 32 policy papers4 prepared 
under  the  2003  economic  policy  network  TA  will  be  undertaken.  An  action  plan  for 
implementation of the policy papers will be prepared to guide follow-up activities. Policy papers 
on specific issues identified under the thematic clusters will be prepared during the course of TA 
implementation.  Policy  dialogue  will  be  undertaken  through  regular  national  and  local 
workshops and seminars, as well as informal consultations with stakeholders. In an effort to 
deepen the ownership of the policy recommendations by the Government, proposals will be 
sought from Government agencies, public policy institutions, and private sector associations by 
the focal unit to seek financial assistance for research and analysis on policy issues. A template 
for the proposal and evaluation criteria will be developed to ensure uniformity of the process.  
 
9.  The TA will develop 2–3 options for institutionalizing the economic policy network in the 
Government system during the first 6 months of TA implementation. These options will be 
submitted to the steering committee for endorsement of one feasible option for establishing an 
operational network. The organization structure, operating procedures, and terms of reference 
will be developed within 12 months of TA commencement. Private sector and civil society 
participation during the process and their integration into the institutional mechanism will be 
ensured to achieve independence and transparency to the institution. Modalities needed for 
proper  monitoring  and  evaluation  of  the  activities  and  policy  actions  will  be  adopted.  A 
dissemination strategy will be developed to widely disseminate the TA outputs by using all forms 
of media. The dissemination material will take into account the language and education status of

the target audience. This will enhance the understanding of the general public about the policy 
reform agenda and the process being followed for policy formulation.  
 
10.  ADB will finance the studies, workshops, and seminars, as well as some of the costs 
borne in establishing the institution. The TA activities include the following: (i) establish a focal 
unit, steering committee, and thematic committees; (ii) support planning and review meetings of 
the steering committee; (iii) identify specific research topics under each thematic cluster; (iv) 
prepare the template for the proposal and evaluation criteria; (v) commission policy studies, 
monitor progress, and assess performance; (vi) prepare policy papers and a dissemination 
strategy; (vii) conduct local consultations and expert technical workshops; (viii) develop options 
for institutionalizing the network, and operating guidelines for the institution; (ix) hold policy 
seminars for opinion makers and stakeholders; and (x) produce and widely disseminate the 
reports. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $600,000. ADB will provide $500,000 on a grant 
basis  from  ADB’s  TA  funding  program.  The  main  components  to  be  funded  by  ADB  are 
consultants, equipment, workshops and seminars, and administration support. The Government 
will contribute $100,000 equivalent to provide office accommodation, counterpart staff support, 
facilities for seminars and meetings, and other administrative expenses. Details of the cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  Executing Agency. The Ministry of Finance (MOF) will be the Executing Agency. The 
thematic  committee,  in  consultation  with  the  high-level  advisory  committee  and  executive 
committee, will identify the implementing agencies. The high-level advisory committee chaired 
by the vice chair of the National Planning Commission will be formed to provide strategic 
guidance, monitor TA progress, and take all necessary actions to facilitate TA implementation. 
The  committee  will  comprise  the  National  Planning  Commission  member  responsible  for 
macroeconomic policies, secretary of MOF, secretary of the National Planning Commission, 
governor  of  Nepal  Rastra  Bank,  representatives  of  the  private  sector  and  policy  research 
institutions, and individual experts. Private sector representatives will make up at least half of 
the  committee.  An  executive  committee  chaired  by  secretary,  MOF  and  comprised  of 
secretaries from the line agencies representing the thematic clusters and Nepal Rastra Bank, 
will also be formed to undertake the TA implementation. The implementation arrangements will 
be reviewed during implementation to provide flexibility and ensure smooth implementation. 
 
13.  Thematic Committee. A thematic committee will be formed for each theme comprising 
senior experts from the public and private sectors. The committees will be responsible for 
identifying sector-specific policy issues, preparing work plans, and engaging in policy dialogue 
with the stakeholders. The committee will select individuals and policy research institutions in 
Nepal on a competitive basis to undertake policy research activities on identified policy issues. 
The committee will be supported by a thematic expert who will help solicit and evaluate the 
proposals, and prepare terms of reference for the specific expertise required to undertake 
research and analysis. 
 
14.  Focal Unit. The economic analysis and policy affairs division of MOF will serve as the 
focal unit of the network. The focal unit will (i) support all activities related to the thematic 
committees, (ii) assist in building capacity, (iii) arrange for peer review and public discourse,

5                         
   
(iv) maintain and update the web portal and disseminate information, and (v) consolidate 
progress reports for the committees and disburse funds. The focal unit will be shifted to the 
proposed institution after its establishment. 
 
15.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  over  24  months  from  March  2008  to  February  2010. 
Tripartite meetings of the Government, TA consultants, and ADB will be chaired by the MOF 
secretary and held semiannually or as and when needed to review TA implementation priorities, 
address issues arising during TA implementation, and provide guidance to the TA consultants. 
The high-level advisory committee and executive committee will meet at the beginning of the TA 
and every 4 months thereafter to guide the TA and resolve policy and implementation issues. 
The thematic committees will meet once every 2 months to sustain the momentum of the policy 
research agenda.  
 
16.  Consulting Services. Three person-months of international and 68 person-months of 
national consulting services will be provided during the TA. The consultants will be recruited 
through a firm using the quality- and cost-based system in accordance with ADB's Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time); the distribution of weights to 
technical  and  financial  proposals  will  be  80:20.  The  team  leader,  institutional  specialist, 
thematic specialists, and information dissemination specialist will be recruited at the beginning 
of  the  TA.  The  remaining  pool  of  consultants  will  be  selected  after  the  policy  issues  are 
identified by the thematic committees. National consultants will be required to prepare policy 
papers on the issues assigned by the team leader under the guidance of the steering and 
thematic committees. Outline terms of reference for the consulting services are attached in 
Appendix  3.  Limited  equipment  will  be  procured  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement 
Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time), and will be handed over to the Government 
on completion. 
 
17.  The team leader will submit an inception report including a detailed work program for the 
TA to the focal unit, high-level advisory committee, executive committee, and ADB within 30 
days of commencement of the TA. A quarterly progress report and midterm report will be 
submitted to the focal unit and ADB; the draft final report will be submitted 1 month prior to and 
a final report upon completion of the TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Nepal for Economic Policy Network II, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

Appendix 3     9 
TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTING SERVICES 
 
1.  Economic  Policy  Networking  Specialist  and  Team  Leader  (national,  
12 person-months). The specialist will undertake the following: 
 
(i)  Help the technical assistance (TA) focal unit to oversee and coordinate overall 
TA  implementation  and  activities,  and  ensure  supervision  and  timely 
submission of individual consulting reports to the Government. 
(ii)  Assist  the  steering  committee  in  forming  the  thematic  subcommittees  and 
preparing proposal template and evaluation criteria for research and analysis 
on the policy issues. 
(iii)  Work with the international consultant to identify operating modalities for the 
network using international best practices.  
(iv)  Assist the thematic committees in evaluating and selecting proposed issues 
for analysis. 
(v)  Help all concerned agencies and committees prepare detailed scopes of work 
for national consultants.  
(vi)  Work  with  the  international  consultant  to  assist  the  Government  in 
establishing  the  economic  policy  network  (EPN)  secretariat  and  develop 
operating guidelines. 
(vii)  Ensure quality outputs from the informed research and arrange for its proper 
dissemination to all users.  
(viii)  Support proper dissemination of TA outputs.  
(ix)  Prepare a public–private partnership modality for monitoring and evaluation of 
implementation of the policy reform agenda. 
(x)  Contribute to development of electronic platforms for sharing the research 
works using facilities such as web portals and other similar means.  
(xi)  Assist  the  Ministry  of  Finance  and  other  agencies  in  organizing  periodic 
seminars and presentations to consolidate the networking constituency. 
(xii)  Organize  and  participate  in  steering  committee,  thematic  committee,  and 
tripartite meetings; seminars; local consultations; and workshops.  
(xiii)  Maintain  proper  coordination  between  the  Government  and  ADB,  and 
undertake other tasks as required by the steering committee and ADB. 
(xiv)  Maintain strict accountability at all times as per contractual obligations and 
reporting requirements. 
 
2.  Institutional Economic Policy Networking Specialist (international, 3 person-months). 
The specialist will have the following responsibilities: 
 
(i)  Advise the Ministry of Finance on the scope of the network to deepen and 
widen  its  coverage,  and  the  modalities  to  bring  the  stakeholders  together 
based on international best practice. 
(ii)  Contribute in the inception meetings, and report and develop the formulation 
process  and  operating  modalities  for  institutionalizing  the  EPN  based  on 
suitable and successful international best practice. 
(iii)  Contribute to developing the terms of reference for each thematic committee. 
(iv)  Contribute  to  developing  the  template  for  the  proposal  on  specific  policy 
issues for research and analysis to be used by the line ministries and other 
stakeholders for consideration of the thematic committee. 
(v)  Share international experience and knowledge of economic policy networking 
and advise on appropriate options for Nepal.

10        Appendix 3 
(vi)  Identify the options for institutionalizing the network and suggest the best 
option for Nepal. 
(vii)  Help  design  the  monitoring  and  follow-up  actions  to  assess  progress  in 
institutionalizing the EPN.  
(viii)  Contribute to development of electronic platforms for sharing the research works 
using facilities such as web portals and similar means.  
(ix)  Undertake other tasks as required by the steering committee and ADB.  
(x)  Maintain strict accountability at all times as per contractual obligations and 
reporting requirements. 
 
3.  Thematic Specialists (18 person-months requiring 6 national consultants; 3 person 
months for each of the six themes). Activities include the following: 
 
(i)  Assist the team leader in preparing and finalizing the template for the proposal. 
(ii)  Assist  the  team  leader  in  setting  up  the  thematic  committees  and  selecting 
implementing agencies. 
(iii)  Coordinate and report on the activities undertaken by each thematic committee 
to the team leader and the steering committee. 
(iv)  Assist  the  line  agencies  in  developing  areas  of  studies  based  on  thorough 
analysis of needs.  
(v)  Assist the team leader in evaluating and selecting the proposals received under 
the respective thematic group. 
(vi)  Assist the team leader in identifying and short-listing consultants. 
(vii)  Support the overall activities of the thematic committee.  
(viii)  Coordinate and support the team leader in conducting thematic workshops and 
consultations. 
(ix)  Support the EPN once it is established within the government system. 
 
4.  Information Dissemination Specialist (national, 2 person-months). Activities of the 
specialist will include the following: 
 
(i)  Prepare dissemination strategy for wide distribution of policy prepared under the 
TA. 
(ii)  Review the policy papers before they are made available to the public. 
(iii)  Regularly update the website ensuring uploading of latest policy papers. 
(iv)  Liaise  with  local  newspapers  and  other  media  (both  electronic  and  print)  in 
establishing links of economic policy network in their websites. 
(v)  Maintain proper documentation of reports prepared under the TA. 
 
5.  Pool  of  National  Consultants  (national, 36 person-months). Policy studies will be 
undertaken under each thematic area based on the proposal received from the line ministries 
and other stakeholders including the private sector and civil society. Specific consultant inputs 
and terms of reference will be prepared by the team leader in consultation with the steering and 
thematic committees and ADB, based on the proposal received.
